Shani Shingnapur is home to nearly 4,000 people and all the houses in this village do not have doors or locks. You’ll just find the door frame. This is because of the villager’s immense and undying faith in the Hindu deity, Shani Dev (Lord of the planet Saturn). According to villagers, Lord Shani watches over the village and protects them from the evil eye. It is said that whoever attempts to steal here will immediately be punished with mental imbalance, blindness or long sickness, and whoever does anything wrong or dishonest will suffer from Sade-Sati, a period of seven-and-a-half years of bad luck—either through an accident, death, or bankruptcy. According to the local folklore, once, a villager tried to put wooden panes at the entrance of his house, and the very next day, he died in a car accident.

The Story Behind No Door or Locks in This Village

According to the legends, about 400 years ago, due to incessant rains, a slab of black stone washed up on the banks of the Panasnala River in the branches of a berry tree, and when the local shepherd prodded the stone boulder with a pointed rod, blood started dribbling from the stone. Later that night, Lord Shanaishwar (God Shani) came into the dream of the most devoted shepherd and told him that the slab of black stone was his own idol. The shepherd asked Lord Shani whether he should build a temple for him, which Lord Shani denied. Lord Shani said that this slab should be installed in the village, where he would reside. Further, he said that no roof or shelter was to be built over his idol, thus enabling him to keep an eye over the village without any hindrance, and he promised to protect the whole hamlet from any kind of danger or mishap. And, since then, the whole village got rid of all the locks and doors, leaving their money and jewelry unsecured, with a belief that Lord Shani is watching them and will keep them protected. Today, Lord Shanaishwar stands in an open yard without a roof.

In fact, the post office and shops in this village also do not have doors. In 2011, the UCO bank opened a lockless branch in Shani Shingnapur, the first of its kind in India. However, the bank has a glass entrance and a remote-controlled electromagnetic lock that is hardly visible, thus maintaining the traditional belief. In 2015, a police station opened in the area, again with no doors. The crime rate in this village is near zero.

While some of the villagers are now installing doors and locks, most villagers still believe in the age-old tradition of no doors and continue to follow it.

Instagram
http://instagram.com/p/BVYlnwcgC-5/

What once was a humble shrine has now become a huge iconic temple housing the deity of Lord Shani, kept on a raised platform in an open environment. This temple draws around 40,000 devotees every day to seek the blessings of Lord Shani. On Amavasya (the new moon day), the temple attracts over three lakhs devotees from across the country and beyond. A fair is held in honor of the God Shani on the new moon day and devotees bathe the idol with oil and water, offer flowers, and seek his blessings.

How do earthquake resistant buildings work?

If a building's foundation sits on soft or filled-in soil, the whole building may fail in an earthquake regardless of the advanced engineering techniques employed.

However, if the soil beneath a structure is firm and solid, engineers can greatly improve how the building-foundation system will respond to seismic waves by tying the foundation to the building so the whole structure moves as a unit.

Another technique-- known as base isolation -- involves floating a building above its foundation on a system of bearings, springs or padded cylinders. Usually lead-rubber bearings, which contain a solid lead core wrapped in alternating layers of rubber and steel are chosen for this purpose. The lead core makes the bearing stiff and strong in the vertical direction, while the rubber and steel bands make the bearing flexible in the horizontal direction. Bearings attach to the building and foundation via steel plates and then, when an earthquake hits, allow the foundation to move without moving the structure above it. As a result, the building's horizontal acceleration is reduced and suffers far less deformation and damage.

Even with a base-isolation system in place, a building still receives a certain amount of vibrational energy during an earthquake. The building itself can dissipate, or damp, this energy to some extent, although its capacity to do this is directly related to the ductility of the material used in the construction. Brick and concrete buildings have low ductility and therefore absorb very little energy. This makes them especially vulnerable in even minor earthquakes. Buildings constructed of steel-reinforced concrete, on the other hand, perform much better because the embedded steel increases the ductility of the material. And buildings made of structural steel offer the highest ductility, allowing buildings to bend considerably without breaking.

Installing damping systems is also an effective technique to protect the building from earthquakes. Active mass damping, for example, relies on a heavy mass mounted to the top of a building and connected to viscous dampers that act like shock absorbers. When the building begins to oscillate, the mass moves in the opposite direction, which reduces the amplitude of mechanical vibrations. It's also possible to use smaller damping devices in a building's brace system.

Which is the oldest Hindu temple which still exists?

The Kanchi Kailasanathar Temple

This temple is located in Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu, India. Kanchi Kailasanathar is a Hindu temple in the Dravidian architectural style. It is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is known for its historical importance. The temple was built from 685-705 AD by a Rajasimha ruler of the Pallava Dynasty.

It is one of the earliest structural temples and the largest one built by the Pallavas.

The Kanchi Kailasanathar Temple

This temple is located in Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu, India. Kanchi Kailasanathar is a Hindu temple in the Dravidian architectural style. It is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is known for its historical importance. The temple was built from 685-705 AD by a Rajasimha ruler of the Pallava Dynasty.

It is one of the earliest structural temples and the largest one built by the Pallavas.

It is of stone-built architecture unlike the rock-cut architecture built into hallowed caves or carved into rock outcrops as in Mahabalipuram. The tall gopuram (tower) is to the left and the temple complex is to the right. The temple's foundations are made of granite, which could withstand the weight of the temple, while the superstructure, including the carvings, are all made of sandstone.

Facts About Kanchi Kailasanathar Temple

  1. The most famous Brihadeshwara Temple in Thanjavur is inspired by Kailasanathar Temple.
  2. A passage is there inside the shrine. One has to crawl inside the passage and climb several steps to reach the exit. It is believed that this passage is symbolic of life and death.

Kanchipuram, one of India’s oldest continuously inhabited cities is often called the land of a thousand temples, and beautiful temples are the crowning glory of the magnificent city. If you are visiting Chennai don’t miss this.

Tips for the Temple visit

  • It is around 70 kilometres from Chennai.
  • Temple is open from 6 AM -12 PM and then 4 PM-9 PM
  • It is a very photogenic temple. Thankfully photography is permitted, except inside the sanctum.

Which temples in India performs tantric practices?

Most North Indian temple rituals are conducted according to the Puranas and they are referred to as mandir. In a mandir you do not have to have a specifically consecrated temple priest (dīkṣita arcaka). Anyone from any community, men, women, gender fluid, race or caste is entitled to perform puja - with the scantiest amount of training - known as a pūjāri or pūjarinī.

All South Indian temples are built, managed and have their rituals performed according to the Āgamas/Tantras. In these temples, built according to strict rules and measurements of Sacred Architecture the ceremonies can only be performed by special priests - males and brahmins (some non-brahmins are now being trained to serve in the temples.) The priests undergo several years of training in the Tantric rituals as young lads and are then formally initiated into the temple priesthood through maṇḍala dīkṣa rites.

Once thus consecrated they take up service in one of ālayas — technical word for a “Tantric” temple.

As a clarificatory note for the uninformed; TANTRA simply means tanayati jñānam anena iti tantra. “Tantra is that (system) by which knowledge is spread.”

The Saiva and Vaishnava canon of Tantra are called Āgamas and those of the Goddess are referred to as Tantras. Both terms are interchangeable.

The Tantrik path is bifurcated into Right-hand Tantra (dakṣinācāra) and Left-hand (vāmācāra - Vamachara - Wikipedia).

Right-handed Tantra or more specifically Āgama, is patriarchal, orthodox, conventional and symbolic in its usages and practices and dedicated only to universal well-being.

Left-handed Tantra on the other hand is matriarchal, heterodox, transgressional in practice and inverts and subverts all the “brahminical” norms and structures and social values.

Which temple is the oldest in India?

Oldest Temple In India: Mundeshwari Devi Temple

Mundeshwari devi temple is known as oldest temple in India; is located at Kaura in Kaimur district in the state of Bihar. It is located on the Mundeshwari Hill at an elevation of 608 feet (185 m) .

It is dedicated to the worship of Lord Shiva and Shakti. This temple has sculptures of other Gods and Goddesses as well which includes Lord Ganesha, Surya and Vishnu. Many say it to be the oldest temple in world to be functional till now.

As per the prevalent version, the temple was built in the period of 3-4 BC with the Narayana, or Vishnu, as the presiding deity. The statue of Narayana has disappeared due to the ravages of time. During 348 AD, a new deity Viniteswara was set up as a minor deity in the temple, holding a subsidiary position to Narayana, the main deity.

Around the seventh century AD, Shaivism became the prevalent religion and Viniteswara, which was a minor deity, emerged as the presiding deity of the temple. The Chatur Mukhalingam (Lingam with four faces) representing him was accorded the central place in the temple, which it holds even now.

After this period, the Cheros, a powerful aboriginal tribe and the original inhabitants of the Kaimur hills, ascended to power. The Cheros were worshippers of Shakti, as represented by Mundeswari, also known as Maheshmardini and Durga. Mundeswari was made the main deity of the temple. However, Mukhalingam still occupied centre stage in the temple. So the image of Durga was installed in a niche along one wall of the temple, where it resides to this day, while the Mukhalingam survives as the subsidiary deity, though in a central position.

The inscription of an information plaque erected by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) at the site indicates the dating of the temple to 108 AD. However, there are other versions for the dating stating the Saka era, prior to Gupta dynasty rule (320 AD) in India, and specifically to 105 AD according to the Administrator of the Bihar Religious Trust Board.

It is believed that rituals and worship have been performed here without a break, hence Mundeshwari is considered one of the most ancient Hindu temples in India. The temple is visited by a large number of pilgrims each year, particularly during the navami, Shivratri festivals. A big annual fair is held nearby during the Navratri visited by thousands.

The temple, built of stone, is on an octagonal plan which is rare. It is the earliest specimen of the Nagara style of temple architecture in Bihar. There are doors or windows on four sides and small niches for the reception of statues in the remaining four walls. The temple shikhara or tower has been destroyed. However, a roof has been built, as part of renovation work. The interior walls have niches and bold mouldings which are carved with vase and foliage designs. At the entrance to the temple, the door jambs are seen with carved images of Dvarapalas, Ganga, Yamuna and many other murtis. The main deities in the sanctum sanctorum of the temple are of the Devi Mundeshwari and Chaturmukh (four faced) Shiva linga. There are also two stone vessels of unusual design. Even though the Shiva linga is installed in the centre of the sanctum, the main presiding deity is Devi Mundeshwari deified inside a niche, which is seen with ten hands holding symbols riding a buffalo, attributed to Mahishasuramardini. The temple also has murtis of other popular gods such as Ganesha, Surya and Vishnu. A substantial part of this stone structure has been damaged, and many stone fragments are seen strewn around the temple. However, under the jurisdiction of ASI, it has been the subject of archaeological study for quite some time.

The plate at the site of the Temple gives a dates of 625 CE for the Temple. Hindu inscriptions dated 635 CE were found in the temple.

Do you believe in astrology, and why or why not?

I never used to believe in Astrology and would hate it when my parents would follow it. But as life is unpredictable, I ended up believing in it and became one of those. Below is my story:

I often come across this question from my friends in a very astonishing way, “How come you into Astrology?,” as I had mocked everyone who ever talked about astrology. However, today I can share my journey with everyone.

Back in 2013, I quit my job with Nomura to pursue my dreams but things didn’t go as planned and I struggled for a year and exhausted my savings. To make ends meet, I went back to Mumbai and did some odd jobs as I was not getting shortlisted for any technology job interviews, citing a gap of one year. After some networking, an old colleague referred me to BNP Paribas and I got the job at a pay cut.

After working there for a year, I got in touch with one of my school friends, who later went to IIT Delhi, and we both planned to start an IT services company. It was time to put down the papers yet again, and I typed the resignation letter with full enthusiasm (that time I didn’t have to look for email templates on Google) but I got very anxious before sending it, as the old struggling days started haunting me.

As I was staring dead at the resignation email, one of my colleagues came over and inquired, “Is everything okay? You look lost.” I showed her my resignation letter and told her how my negative thoughts are not letting me do what I wanted to.

She looked at me with empathy and said, “I can see your birth chart and tell you what to do as per Astrology. What are your birth details?” and she opened one very badly designed app on her phone to input my details. I was shocked and amused at the same time. I promised myself to hire good UI/UX designers to develop better apps than that).

“Seriously? Do you think I believe in all this? Padhe likhe hoke aap andh vishwas faila rahe ho!” I scolded her but I wished I could get some help.

She waited for me to complete and demanded, “Are you done? Now tell me your birth details. I don’t care if you believe or not but let me try to help.” I shared the details as I would rather not mess with a senior. But knowing her coding skills, I could totally judge that she would screw up in Astrology as well.

As she was analysing my chart, I waited curiously to know the outcome, the way I had waited for my 10th standard board results. There is something about Astrology, it doesn’t matter whether you believe in it or not, but it fascinates you like nothing else. However, as I didn’t trust her and would never have liked to take a biased decision based on Astrology, so I quickly sent the resignation letter and locked my screen. Meanwhile, she was done with her calculations and it was time for the results.

“You are Leo Ascendant and your Sun is exalted…” I interrupted her in between and asked, “I don’t understand all this. Tell me something about the past to make me believe you,” I was such a spoiler.

“Beta, jitna tu bhaagta hai na isse, aage jake utna jaada believe karega (Dear, as much as you are mocking this today, you will believe in it much more, in future),” She mocked me this time but after hearing that I was convinced she knew Astrology as good as Database designing, as I would never do that.

“You don’t choose Astrology, Astrology chooses you”

Then she told me many things about my past to make her point including the date of my accident in school days, which was shocking. And once she observed the change in my body language, she stopped telling about the past and came to the main question. She not only predicted the past correctly but was also such a nice observer of behaviour. Oh God! Why the hell was she a MySQL developer?

“Yes, you can quit your job as the next two years are very promising for an IT business as per the placement of Saturn and Rahu,” she smiled as she made the prediction. I am still not sure if that smile was for a positive prediction or for the virtual win over me.

“Just two years?,” I exclaimed with a sheepish laugh as I had to pretend that I was not interested.

Like every other story, this story was also filled with some twist and turns. The twist was that my business partner might leave after two years from then and I would face some issues in resuming the business and it might take a year to pivot to a new venture, “But you will make it” she assured after observing my not-so-good body language.

“You can press the send button,” she finally said something with a real smile as she observed that I wasn’t mocking anymore and had surrendered myself, unlike a Leo.

After that, I served my notice period and came to Noida and started an IT services company named CodeYeti in April 2015. We managed to scale up very quickly to 45 employees, serving about 15-20 clients at a time and clocked a revenue of $0.5 million in the first year itself. We started working for big enterprises like Yamaha, GreenPly along with startups.

Everything was going well until my partner told me that he is not getting a kick from the services business and wanted to do a tech product. We spent the next six months on two products but ended up wasting capital as nothing seemed to work and he finally quit in March 2017 to do something else.

And that reminded me about the prediction, my ex-colleague had made about my partner’s exit. I called her after a gap of two years (Let’s just assume that I was busy and was not bad at keeping in touch) and told her about the prediction.

I could sense the happiness in her voice as her prediction came true but she showed concern as it was a loss for me. To my surprise, she knew everything about CodeYeti as she followed our social media channels and congratulated me for what we had achieved in such a short duration.

“Do you want me to check your chart again?” she inquired.

I paused for a moment and proposed an idea, “How about I start a product in the field of Astrology and I become your first customer?” She halted for a few seconds and said, “Hmmm…I had quit my job four months back for some personal reasons, and I can take out some time to work with you but I won’t be very active, so you will have to find more astrologers. I can connect you with a few in my network”

“Yes Yes! You can work whenever you have time and you can interview and train other astrologers and we will keep hiring. You can become their mentor and take care of the department of Astrologers”, I said in excitement.

“Hmm…So, when are we going live?” she straight away asked for a deadline, the way she did at BNP. Some people never change.

And then, there was the ultimate turn – I worked on developing the product and launched an MVP (minimum viable product) of AstroTalk within a month and assigned a dedicated technology & operations team to it. I called her as a customer and asked, “How would AstroTalk do?”

———————————————————————————————————–

Current stats:

Total Installs: 95,00,000+

No of Astrologers: 5000+

Daily Consultations with Astrologers: 3,20,000 minutes over chat/call

Revenue: INR 70,00,000 daily

Repeat Rate: 13+ (Higher than Swiggy)

Rating: 4.9/5.0 (Highest in this industry)

Within 4.5 years of launch, we have changed the way people interact with Astrologers and gave 20+ years old companies a run for their money. There were two basic fundamental problems with companies in this industry, which we could fix very precisely.

  • Companies were run by Astrologers who lacked technology expertise and made a very low-quality product with the worst possible customer experience.
  • Companies were run by some decent technology people (still lacked a good UI/UX design) who had no idea about how to build a business. They just focused on making money and offered no customer delight. Customer support was so poor that they had a very poor repeat rate in an industry with such high demands.

However, I feel the biggest reason we could do so well was that I never believed in Astrology as I had seen so many fake astrologers my entire life, predicting everything incorrectly, which made people like me hate the concept of Astrology.

However, after getting an accurate prediction about my partner’s exit, even before starting the partnership, I started believing in it and I realized that ‘the Astrologer could be wrong, but Astrology is always right.‘ So, I made sure we appoint the best in the list of professional Astrologer online for astrology today.

It is not easy to get a place on our panel as we have a special recruitment team that reaches out to the best Astrologer in India, and we make them go through multiple case studies and interviews, to be sure about their prediction quality and communications skills.

(AstroTalk Team)

When did door-to-door salesmanship start in India?

Door to Door salesmanship in India might have begun to get organized in 70s with people starting to sell soaps, incense-sticks, washing powder door to door with the introduction of Doorbells, catalogues and purchase orders, sale receipts.

But this salesmanship in an unorganized way has been present in India since eternity. My grandmother used to tell me that since the time she recollected, salesmen who used to go door to door to sell Banarsi sarees, clothes, Kashmiri Carpets and shawls, chairs, spices, dry fruits, pickles, tea, Asafetida "Heeng", Pestle (stone spice grinders), Batu giling, fa

Door to Door salesmanship in India might have begun to get organized in 70s with people starting to sell soaps, incense-sticks, washing powder door to door with the introduction of Doorbells, catalogues and purchase orders, sale receipts.

But this salesmanship in an unorganized way has been present in India since eternity. My grandmother used to tell me that since the time she recollected, salesmen who used to go door to door to sell Banarsi sarees, clothes, Kashmiri Carpets and shawls, chairs, spices, dry fruits, pickles, tea, Asafetida "Heeng", Pestle (stone spice grinders), Batu giling, farming tools, etc. were very common. There were no doorbells but salesmen had their voice.

Most of us must have heard the famous story "Kabuliwala" by Rabindra Nath Tagore which is the moving tale of an a middle-aged Afgan dry fruit door to door seller trying to earn a living in faraway Calcutta.

Its not just sales of goods, different door to door services were also available. services like repair of furniture, carpets, mattresses, quilt, key makers, sharpening of farming tools, repair of the roofs of the clay house, silage making, etc. were available at the doorsteps.

If we may call these door to door sellers as direct sellers then early direct sellers in the form of hawkers, peddlers, traders, itinerant merchants and caravans are part of an ancient tradition that originated in man’s basic need to exchange goods and to communicate. Doorbells, catalogues and purchase orders were centuries away from the early direct seller who relied on his instincts and common sense to make a living through selling.
As they established economic ties with their neighbors, they traveled extensively despite geographical barriers. The development and use of roads and or water routes for commercial activity were pivotal points in the history of direct selling.

Yashwant Kumar
Lives in India (1990–present) · Author has 775 answers and 29.3M answer views · Updated 5y ·

What is India’s richest temple?

The top 3 richest temples in India are:

With a wealth more than 80,000 Crore Rupees($12 Billion), Sri Venkateswara Swamy Temple in Andhra Pradesh is the second richest temple in India. With an estimated wealth of nearly 1000 Crore Rupees($1.5 Billion), Shirdi Sai Baba Temple is the third richest temple in India.

I saw Lord Venkateswara’s temple and statue in a dream. I liked their song, even though I didn’t understand the meaning of it. It felt like something related to the South Indian image of God Venkatesh. What does this mean?

Let me quickly narrate one incident that occurred to me and then let’s try to draw parallels with your dream.

It was early months of 2004 when I was without a job and lying in my bachelor room without much things to do apart from preparing for interviews.

Let me quickly narrate one incident that occurred to me and then let’s try to draw parallels with your dream.

It was early months of 2004 when I was without a job and lying in my bachelor room without much things to do apart from preparing for interviews.

I cannot recollect how or why, but suddenly I felt like visiting Tirupati for a Darshan. I immediately took by bike out and rode to a travel agent in the central area and booked a Tirupati Darshan package for the weekend.

This was my first time visiting the Temple town and it went well without any hiccups. I don’t remember the month of my visit, but I was lucky since it was less crowded and I was blessed to have a Darshan very close to the Main Deity.

I still remember those moments, I was overwhelmed by the sight of the statue. It was Majestic and I was awestruck by the sight. I folded my hands and along with many other things, I begged him for a good job, and if I got it soon, I would donate half of my first salary at the feet of the Lord.

I came back to Bangalore and continued with my routine. In few months, I cracked a difficult interview and landed a good job. Months and years passed and I didn’t even remember of my promise to Lord Venkateswara.

Fast forward to 2009 - five years in my job and I had already got promoted to a mid-level engineering position. I was still in my own sweet little world, unaware that someone was waiting for me to abide by my promise.

And then one night, the unexpected happened. I had a dream where Lord Venkateswara visited me! I don’t know if I can still call it as a simple dream because the Lord was standing there in all his full glory – the huge black statue was staring at me, standing exactly in the pose he was when I had promised him the donation. He just uttered the words “Where is the money you had promised?”. I woke up, gasping for breath. Yes, it was a dream but it felt too real to just brush it off as a dream. Perhaps it was my subconscious mind playing tricks but I cannot explain what I saw.

The very next morning I booked my tickets for Tirupati. I visited and begged for forgiveness. I paid half of my salary as I had promised. Half of my 2009 salary and not my first salary. I owed it to the Lord.

When I returned back Home to Bangalore, there were difficult changes happening at my work place. Our unit was closed and sold to a different company. I survived the transition and came out strong in the new organization. Perhaps it was God’s way of holding my hand and also remind me of my promise.

Some things don’t have logical explanation. No matter how much I try to rationalize that night’s “dream”, I cannot explain it. The Lord standing in front of me was too real to be wished off as a dream.

Now, coming to your dream, since you too have seen the Temple and Statue, and since Hinduism emphasis on the point of Karma transcending births, and since I have had a similar experience, I can only think of an unfulfilled promise by You or by someone else in your family. It’s time you visit him!

Were many Buddhist temples converted into Hindu temples in India?

There is very little credible evidence that this has happened - if so I would like to see it.

I don’t know about North India but in South India all Hindu temples are built strictly according to the dictates of the Āgama Śāstra and have very specific requirements in terms of location, orientation, measurements, dimensions, sculptures, peripheral shrines etc.

And each temple is consecrated with elaborate rituals specific to the deity enshrined in the temple. So there is absolutely no possibility of a Buddhist temple, which has none of these requirements being turned into a Hindu temple.

Even Tirupati which some neo-Buddhists allege was once a Buddhist temple is built entirely according to the Dravidian Hindu temple architecture and we actually know who the sponsor was as his details are inscribed on the walls of the temple, so the claim is false.

There is absolutely no provision in any of the Shilpa literature of India for the renovation and transforming of a temple of one deity into that of another. Temples are purpose built, and a Shiva temple can never be used as a Vishnu temple or vice versa. People who claim this are totally ignorant of the very nature of the temple architecture and rituals associated with temple building.

P.S. One may note in passing that the biggest Hindu temple on earth Angkor Wat has been converted into a Buddhist temple.

What is the real mystery behind Padmanabhaswamy Temple's seventh vault?

On the bequest of the Supreme Court of India the seven member committee in the presence of the Head Trustee of Travencore Trust of Sri Anantha Padmanabha Swamy temple at Tiruvananthapur in Kerala have opened the six secret vaults.

They have discovered under 20 feet of the ground approximately $ 22 BILLION (6000CrX22= Rs 1,32,000 Cr)WORTH OF HIGHLY VALUABLE GOLD in the form of, diamond jewelry, golden utensils, weapons, golden idols, golden elephants idols and diamond necklaces having 500 kilograms weight and 18 feet length and bags full of golden coins of different nations, including NAPOLEON and ITALIAN coins in the last one week. With this Sri Anantha Padmanabha Swamy of Tiruvnanthapuram has emerged the richest God on the earth.

Chambers:

The temple management authorities were aware of the existence of six vaults. They are situated very close to the middle of the temple on its western side just below where the deity is placed.

For documentation purposes, these vaults have been designated as vaults A, B, C, D, E and F.

Subsequently, two more vaults have been identified and they have been designated as vaults G and H.

  • Four vaults C, D, E, and F, are in the custody of the temple priests and have been/are opened at least eight times every year and the contents stored in them are routinely taken out for use on special ceremonial occasions.
  • As per the orders of the Supreme Court of India, a court appointed committee opened the vaults on 30 June 2011 and entered vault A. They unlocked an iron grille and a heavy wooden door, then removed a granite slab from the floor. Beneath, five or six steps led to a small, dark room which stored the treasure. The various items found scattered everywhere, They were not arranged systematically. There were baskets, earthen pots, copper pots, all containing valuable objects. It took about 12 days to carry the treasure outside, and to take an inventory of it.
  • Vault B has not been opened presumable for centuries. The Supreme Court appointed committee members opened the metal-grille door to Vault B, and discovered a sturdy wooden door just behind it. They opened this door as well, and encountered a third door, made of iron, which was jammed shut. The observers considered forcing their way in, but deemed this improper; they decided to hire a locksmith. Then, in mid-July, before the locksmith came, the royal family got an injunction from the Supreme Court against opening vault B.
  • Vaults G and H also remain closed for centuries believably as of May 2016, but have been opened in late 1800′s and it also had valuables which have been documented that time.

The main vault or the seventh vault is Vault B.

The mysterious door of Vault B

The entire world stands now to know whats behind that door. According to experts, the door was supposed to unlock by itself when a secret chant is spelled, as it is believed that the door is locked in that way

It is believed that this chamber is being consider as highly mysterious,sacred and risky by Trust members and other learned astrologers. The steel door of Chamber B is having two big COBRA PORTRAITS on it and this door has no nuts, bolts or even latches. It is just a plain chunk of steel

The door to such a vault can only be opened by a highly erudite ‘SADHUS’ who are familiar with the knowledge of extricating “NAGA BANDHNAM” by chanting a very sacred and difficult “GARUDA MANTRA”.

According to the legends, if anyone tries to force open this door ,which has “NAGA BANDHAN” on it, then catastrophes are likely to occur throughout the world.

What is the mystery of the sealed temple doors of India?

Immense wealth was accumulated in our well known temples (especially those that had a ‘sthalapurana’) as kings and commoners alike made their contributions in the form of gold, gems or cash. Even after using many ornaments in daily puja and some more during the processions, the wealth was to be kept safe in underground vaults behind seald doors. What is the reason for the small door of a Hindu temple?

Shiva Om Dear Friend,

Different temples have different door sizes. There is no universal rule in regards to the size of the door. In some cases I have come across humongous doors which are required to be opened by at least two or three strong people while one the other hand there are some temples which have very tiny doors and one literally needs to bend to get within the Inner Sanctum Sanctorum.

In my limited experience, knowledge and wisdom I believe their exists a very valid reason for these doors to be really small such that the person who enters it will necessarily need to bend and keep his head down. This is so in order to kill or contain the Ego or Aham factor in any person who is visiting the God / Goddess / Deity.

This creates a sense of humbleness regardless of the position the person holds and when visiting the temple he let’s go his power and authority. He is virtually tamed by bending down and visiting the Almighty. I have personally seen and felt the psychological effect of such doors. One is then able to connect better to the bigger Cosmic force as his “I” ( Ahankar ) has been crushed by the bending and putting his head down as he or she enters the temple premise or the inner sanctum sanctorum.

I earnestly hope that this rather simple answer has effectively resolved your query.

Shivam Kalyanam,

Why is Tirupati Temple the biggest temple in India?

Venkateswara Temple is a Hindu sanctuary situated in the hilly town of Tirumala at Tirupati in the Chittoor locale of Andhra Pradesh, India. The sanctuary is devoted to Venkateswara, a type of Vishnu, who is accepted to have shown up here to save humanity from preliminaries and inconveniences of Kali Yuga. Subsequently, the spot has additionally got the name Kaliyuga Vaikuntha and the Lord here is alluded to as Kaliyuga Prathyaksha Daivam. The sanctuary is additionally known by different names including Tirumala Temple, Tirupati Temple, Tirupati Balaji Temple. Venkateswara is known by numerous

Venkateswara Temple is a Hindu sanctuary situated in the hilly town of Tirumala at Tirupati in the Chittoor locale of Andhra Pradesh, India. The sanctuary is devoted to Venkateswara, a type of Vishnu, who is accepted to have shown up here to save humanity from preliminaries and inconveniences of Kali Yuga. Subsequently, the spot has additionally got the name Kaliyuga Vaikuntha and the Lord here is alluded to as Kaliyuga Prathyaksha Daivam. The sanctuary is additionally known by different names including Tirumala Temple, Tirupati Temple, Tirupati Balaji Temple. Venkateswara is known by numerous different names: Balaji, Govinda, and Srinivasa. The sanctuary is controlled by the body Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD) which is under the direct control of the Andhra Pradesh Government, which additionally designates the head of TTD and utilizations the income from the altar.

The sanctuary is developed in Dravidian architecture and is accepted to be built throughout some stretch of time beginning from 300 AD. The first sanctuary at Tirumala Tirupati was worked by King Thondaiman, Tamil leader of the old Thondaimandalam. He is said to have assembled the first Gopuram (tower) and the Prakhara in the eighth century. The Garbagruha (Sanctum Sanctorum) is called AnandaNilayam. The directing divinity, Venkateswara, is in a standing stance and faces east in Garbha gruha. The sanctuary follows the Vaikhanasa Agama custom of love. The sanctuary is one of the eight Vishnu Swayambhu Kshetras and is recorded as 106th and the last natural Divya Desam. The Temple premises had two current Queue complex structures to sort out the pioneer surge, Tarigonda Vengamamba Annaprasadam complex with the expectation of complimentary suppers to Pilgrims, hair tonsure structures and various traveller dwelling destinations.

It is the most extravagant sanctuary on the planet as far as gifts got and riches. The sanctuary is visited by around 50,000 to 100,000 explorers day by day (30 to 40 million individuals yearly overall), while on special occasions and festivals, similar to the yearly Brahmotsavam, the quantity of travellers shoots up to 500,000, making it the most-visited holy place on the planet.

What can be the logical reason behind the houses in Shani Shingnapur not having doors?
Originally Answered: what can be the logical reason behind the houses in Shani shingnapur not having doors?

They say they have got no doors because that would go against their belief.
The residents of Shani Shingnapur village in the state of Maharashtra do not feel the need for security measures because of their undying faith in the local deity Shani, the God of Saturn. Legend has it that centuries ago, an iron and stone slab washed up on to the shore of a nearby river during a flood. When cattle herders poked the curious slab with a stick, it began oozing blood.
Later that night, Shani appeared in the dream of a the village head and revealed that the slab was his own idol. He told the villager that the idol was so powerful that it did not need to be placed under shelter. He also said that the villagers never needed to install doors again, because he would always protect them from any kind of danger.
“The power of Shani is such that if someone steals, he will keep walking all night and think he has left the village, but when the sun comes up he will still be there,” explained mill worker Balasaheb Borude. It is also believed that anyone who commits sins in the village will have to face ‘Sade Saati’, which means seven-and-a-half years of bad luck. To this day, the five-foot naked slab continues to be worshipped at the local shrine, where it is placed out in the open.
A pamphlet handed out at the shrine claims that Shani Shingnapur is a ‘model village’, not only free from theft but also from all kinds of sinful behavior. “Professional robbers, thieves, dacoits, non-vegetarians, drunkards never come here,” the leaflet states. “If they come, they behave like gentlemen.
This is a belief which have kept people secured until 2010 when the first ever theft of around 30000 rupees was done, and after that many more instances have come out.

What are some popular temples in India?

The most popular temple in India is Tirupati Balaji Temple in Tirumala, Andhra Pradesh, with 30 to 40 million pilgrims per year. I wrote this answer about it:

Devala Rees
· Nov 30
What is the most popular Hindu temple in the world?
The most popular Hindu temple in the world is the ancient Venkateshwara Balaji Temple on the peak of Venkatadri Hill among the seven sacred hills of Tirumala at Tirupati, Chittoor district, Andhra Pradesh, India. It attracts 30,000 to 100,000 visitors per day, just on normal days throughout the year, not even counting big festivals (during which it may hit 500,000). Including festivals, it has 30 to 40 million visitors per year. It provides free meals to all of them. This makes it not only the most popular Hindu temple, but the most popular holy site of any religion in the world. The temple is dedicated to Venkateshwara, a form of Vishnu also known as Balaji, Srinivasa, and Govinda. This local manifestation is specifically to provide salvation during the trying times of Kaliyuga, hence its immense popularity in this present age.

The second-most popular temple in India is Kashi Vishwanath Temple in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, with 22 million pilgrims per year. It is the main temple of the city of Kashi, also called Varanasi, the spiritual capital of India and a strong candidate for the oldest continuously inhabited city on Earth. It is the most revered of the twelve Jyotirlinga temples, the main temples to Shiva, all twelve of which

What is the most popular Hindu temple in the world?
The most popular Hindu temple in the world is the ancient Venkateshwara Balaji Temple on the peak of Venkatadri Hill among the seven sacred hills of Tirumala at Tirupati, Chittoor district, Andhra Pradesh, India. It attracts 30,000 to 100,000 visitors per day, just on normal days throughout the year, not even counting big festivals (during which it may hit 500,000). Including festivals, it has 30 to 40 million visitors per year. It provides free meals to all of them. This makes it not only the most popular Hindu temple, but the most popular holy site of any religion in the world. The temple is dedicated to Venkateshwara, a form of Vishnu also known as Balaji, Srinivasa, and Govinda. This local manifestation is specifically to provide salvation during the trying times of Kaliyuga, hence its immense popularity in this present age.

The second-most popular temple in India is Kashi Vishwanath Temple in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, with 22 million pilgrims per year. It is the main temple of the city of Kashi, also called Varanasi, the spiritual capital of India and a strong candidate for the oldest continuously inhabited city on Earth. It is the most revered of the twelve Jyotirlinga temples, the main temples to Shiva, all twelve of which could well be included in a list like this one. I wrote this answer about its tragic history:

Devala Rees
· 8mo
How many times has the Kashi Vishwanath Temple been destroyed and rebuilt?
Essentially it has been destroyed four times and rebuilt five, though not all in exactly the same location or with the same name. The original temple was called the Vishweshwara Temple. It was destroyed in 1194 by the order of Qutbud-din Aibak, and the Razia Mosque was later built over it. In the late 1200s, the replacement temple had been rebuilt in the Avimukteshwara temple compound. It was destroyed again by the Sharqi kings of Jaunpur sometime between 1435 and 1458. It was soon rebuilt, then destroyed again in the 1490s by Sikandar Lodhi. Then by the patronage of Raghunath Pandit of Kashi, the new Vishweshwara Temple was rebuilt in 1585. It was destroyed yet again by the order of Aurangzeb in 1669, and the Gyanvapi Mosque was built over it, incorporating part of the original structure in a deliberately visibly obvious fashion: Then the Maratha ruler Ahilya Bai Holkar of Indore built the new Kashi Vishwanath Temple in 1780, on a new site, as the mosques still stood over the original sites. By then Muslim rule of India was waning and they were mostly past their temple-destroying days, and sure enough, no one else came to destroy it. The pattern here is abundantly clear.

The third-most popular temple in India is Vaishno Devi Temple, with over 10 million pilgrims per year. This temple is nestled on the Trikuta mountain near Katra in Jammu, marking the spot where the woman Vaishno Devi, considered a Divine incarnation, killed a powerful man who was trying to rape her. I wrote this answer about it:

Devala Rees
· Dec 16
What makes Vaishno Devi such a popular pilgrimage site in India? What aspects of the site distinguish it from other pilgrimage destinations?
This is an interesting question to me, and one whose implications go beyond just Vaishno Devi. India is full of thousands of pilgrimage sites. Their popularity ranges all over the place. Vaishno Devi is the third most popular, with over ten million visitors per year. On the opposite end, many pilgrimage sites are so obscure they’re unheard of by the vast majority of Indians, and only a few people go there, even if they find mention in some ancient scripture. Indeed some pilgrimage sites praised in ancient scriptures became so obscure that they were actually lost, and today no one is sure where exactly the site is that the scripture refers to! So, why are some so popular and others not? What aspects distinguish them from each other and determine their popularity? When an Indian person decides to go on a pilgrimage, how do they choose among the thousands of options? Here are some distinguishing aspects of Vaishno Devi: * Miracle stories flourish around Vaishno Devi. People say that their pilgrimage there restored the use of a crippled or withered limb, or cured their blindness or infertility, brought wealth and good fortune to the desperately poor, or even resurrected their dead baby. Of course such stories are not unique to this one pilgrimage, but even as a Hindu with no particular connection to Vaishno Devi (I’ve never been there, it’s not especially emphasized in my community, etc.), I have the impression that Vaishno Devi is exceptionally miracle-rich (or at least, it is widely claimed to be). I suspect this may be the one of the biggest factors right here. * A traditional answer to this whole question is that Mata Vaishno Devi helped Lord Rama win victory over Ravana, and that he blessed her that the entire world would sing her praises and revere her. So some say that it is Lord Rama’s boon that makes Vaishno Devi such a popular pilgrimage site. * Vaishno Devi is a very ancient pilgrimage site, with the temple already mentioned in the Mahabharata. While this is far from unique - many pilgrimage sites are described in the Mahabharata and other similarly ancient texts - it does set it apart from some of the younger pilgrimages which have had less time to build up popularity. * Vaishno Devi’s connections to Rama and to Kalki give this pilgrimage site holy significance and appeal to Vaishnavas as well as Shaktas. Namdev, a medieval Vaishnava saint, visited Vaishno Devi, further strengthening this inter-sectarian appeal. This sets it apart from the many pilgrimage sites which appeal to only one sect. It is also holy to Sikhs as well as Hindus, having supposedly been visited by Guru Nanak and Guru Gobind Singh. * Its surroundings are visually beautiful, nestled in the green, forested Trikuta Hills. Some of the other most popular pilgrimage sites in India stand out as also being nestled in green hills and/or dramatic mountains, being beside mighty rivers, etc. Many others are in the middle of busy (and often dirty) cities, or in deforested, flat, brown lands of no particular beauty. This may be a relevant factor. * It is far away from most Indians, way up in Jammu in the extreme north of the country. Perhaps this is actually a bonus for its popularity? Maybe pilgrims like to go somewhere a little farther from home? Similarly, once there you have to hike twelve miles and then squeeze through a narrow cave. Again this level of physical engagement, rather than simply driving right to the door of a temple, may be part of the appeal. * It’s a year-round, all-season pilgrimage site. Many Indian pilgrimages are supposed to be performed at certain times of year - but people may not be able to take time off work at that time, etc. If you want to perform a pilgrimage within a certain date range, many options may be closed, but Vaishno Devi is always open. Vaishno Devi is far from unique in this, but it may be a contributing factor. * Once a site becomes highly popular, it can snowball. Vaishno Devi’s sheer fame attracts more pilgrims, which further grows its fame. Also, on a very practical level, Vaishno Devi receives almost $16 million per year in donations. It can afford a big advertising budget, with feature films about Vaishno Devi going back to the 1970s, TV serials, etc. Most individual Indian pilgrimage sites don’t have such a media presence. But in the end, even the combination of all these factors is not all that unique. One could surely find various other pilgrimage sites in India that share many factors like these, and yet are not nearly as popular as Vaishno Devi. Having performed traditional pilgrimages in India myself, and talked with fellow pilgrims on the trails, I found that the above sorts of rationales are not what most Indian pilgrims think about. Rather, they think about Darshan - the holy presence in the temple. It is the experience of millions of pilgrims that not all sites have the same Darshan. Ultimately, I suspect the #1 factor that makes Vaishno Devi so popular is that its sheer palpable sacred power which devotees experience within their consciousness is simply greater than that of the vast majority of other pilgrimage sites. Jai Mata Di!

After those three, the exact order gets increasingly hard to determine, as precise figures on numbers of visitors become less reliable and more difficult to find. But here are some more of the most popular temples in India, not necessarily in order:

  • Guruvayurappan Temple in Guyuvayur, Kerala, dedicated to Lord Krishna. 6 to 10 million devotees visit annually, especially during its spectacular festivals.
  • Akshardham Temple in Delhi, with nearly ten million visitors per year - unsurprising given its convenient location in India’s capital city, and its spectacular size and architectural beauty. This temple is dedicated to the Guru Swaminarayan. I personally have visited it twice with different groups of people while in Delhi.
  • The next most popular temples in India are probably the Char Dham temples, the four great temples appointed by Adi Shankaracharya at the far east, south, west, and north of India. These four temples are the seats of the four lineages of Gurus descending from Adi Shankaracharya, each associated with one of the four Vedas, and together they form one of the most popular pilgrimages in India.
  • The pilgrimage starts with the eastern temple, Shri Jagannath Temple in Puri, Odisha, dedicated to Lord Krishna and His siblings Lord Balabhadra and Goddess Subhadra. It looks out to the east over the Bay of Bengal. This temple is best known for its annual and world-famous Ratha Yatra, when its three Deities ride through the city streets on gigantic and spectacular chariots amid crowds of thousands. It is also famous for its huge and majestic kitchen.
  • Next comes the southern temple, Ramanathaswamy Temple in on the small island of Rameshwaram, Tamil Nadu off the south coast of India, with 8.4 million visitors per year (probably a similar number to the other Char Dham temples). Despite the name, this temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva. Lord Rama and his wife Sita landed here after Rama rescued Sita from the demon king of Lanka, and they along with Hanuman established the worship of Lord Shiva on the spot. It is one of the twelve Jyotirlingas.
  • Then comes the western temple, Dwarkadhish Temple (also called Jagat Temple) in Dwarka, Gujarat on the Arabian Sea, again dedicated to Lord Krishna, who had His holy abode here in person during His Avatarana on Earth.
  • Finally comes the northern temple, the beautiful Badrinath Temple in Chamoli, Uttarakhand, high in the cold and snowy Himalayas near the glacial source of the holy Alakananda river. This temple can be visited only from April to November due to heavy snows. It is dedicated to Vishnu in His form of Nara-Narayana or Badri Narayana. In addition to being the climax of the pan-Indian Char Dham Yatra, Badrinath Temple is also the climax of another Char Dham Yatra local to the Himalayas, the Chota Char Dham Yatra. It is also one of the 108 Divya Desams, temples dedicated to Lord Vishnu, renowned among saints even in the far south of India in ancient times. This holy valley is praised as a domain of great sages in ancient scriptures like the Bhagavata Mahapurana. I have visited this temple, and it is my personal favorite temple in India (so far, at least). I wrote this answer about it:
Devala Rees
· 8mo
What was the most supernatural experience you’ve had at a temple?
It was at the Badrinath Temple in Uttarakhand, India. First of all, two days in a row in that temple I sat down alone, with no one around, closed my eyes in meditation, and immediately experienced a timeless state of inner awareness with no idea of my external surroundings or how much time might be passing; indeed I had no concept of time at all. The next thing of which I was conscious was a feeling that I should ‘wake up’, so to speak. I did so and found that several hours had passed, a crowd of fellow devotees was literally physically pressed up against me without my notice, and a woman was tapping me (and everyone else) on the shoulder and saying it was time to go outside so the pujaris could prepare for upcoming ceremonies. Later, while attending evening Arati to Vishnu in the temple, during the loud and fast ringing of the bells and the waving of flames in ritual patterns before the Swayambhu Murti of Badri Narayana, I saw a vision in the flickering firelight. This was a vivid apparition overriding my physical sight, not something subtle. I saw faces of Vishnu - living, real faces, not carven or painted depictions, and not just one, but another and another, flashing in rapid succession. A palpable energy shot up my spine like a spike, the most powerfully I had ever felt. I was definitely gasping and crying, mostly in a very good way, though it wasn’t entirely comfortable. My vision of the faces coalesced such that I saw all the faces at once, outspread in a sweeping gallery almost, though they were all atop one vast body. Many of them were beautiful, smiling, some feminine (possibly as many as were masculine), shining with light; but many others were quite monstrous in appearance, glaring fiercely (not necessarily at me, but in various directions) and spitting sickly-looking fire or gnashing meat between their fangs. It felt in a way that they were more than faces, that they somehow encapsulated the phenomena of the universe. That vision ended as the pujaris carried the Arati flames over to the devotees (including me), and we took blessings from them. Just as I was finishing doing so, Vishnu laid His hand on my right shoulder. I’m not claiming objective reality of this; certainly the people sitting right next to me didn’t seem to see anything; but it was my experience. I felt it at least as physically as any other sensation. His hand was so hot that any more heat would’ve burned me; it felt like it should’ve scorched my clothes, yet it felt extremely pleasurable. His heat spread through my body in a kind of wave, like a thick, steaming, brothy nectar that tasted like Home. Then the pujaris performed Vishnu Sahasranama and Sahasranamavali. During that long chant (maybe half an hour or so) I actually had one of the most privately meaningful spiritual experiences of my life, but I think I should keep that part to myself for now.
  • About four million pilgrims perform the Chota Char Dham Yatra per year (I was among them in 2010), so I will mention the other three temples of this pilgrimage here. The aforementioned Badrinath is the last. The first is Yamunotri Temple in Uttarkashi district, Uttarakhand, dedicated to the Goddess Yamuna. High in the harsh conditions of the Himalayas, this temple has been repeatedly damaged by natural disasters and rebuilt, and can only be reached on foot, not by roads. Like all of the Chota Char Dham temples, it cannot be visited during the long, harsh Himalayan winter (which includes much of spring and fall as well - the temple is open from Akshaya Tritiya until Diwali).
  • Next comes Gangotri Temple, also in Uttarkashi disrict, Uttarakhand, dedicated to the Goddess Ganga. This temple stands on the spot where Raja Bhagiratha performed rigorous penance for many years to convince Mother Ganga to descend from Heaven to Earth to release his ancestors from a curse, and to bless the land with Her many virtues. So she asked him to persuade Lord Shiva to catch Her so that Her impact wouldn’t break the Earth. Bhagiratha prayed to Shiva, and He agreed to catch Mother Ganga in the twisted locks of His hair, and release Her in a gradual and manageable flow. Originally this temple was right at the Ganga’s glacial source, but with climate change the glacier has retreated some 18 kms further up the mountain, and is now a holy trek from the temple. I personally love Gangotri so much I recently returned to it for a second visit.
  • Then comes Kedarnath Temple in Rudraprayag district, Uttarakhand, a holy abode of Shiva built by the Pandavas to atone for their sins during the Mahabharata, and restored by Adi Shankaracharya. To reach it requires a steep 14 km trek (except for a wealthy few who now take a helicopter!), up into a beautiful panorama of majestic glaciers and snow-clad peaks (much like all the Chota Char Dham sites). It is another of the aforementioned twelve Jyotirlinga temples.
  • Shri Saibaba Samadhi Temple in Shirdi, Maharashtra receives well over 7.3 million pilgrims per year. It is the tomb of the renowned Saint Sai Baba of Shirdi.
  • Palini Murugan Temple in Tamil Nadu, dedicated to Lord Murugan, receives over 7 million pilgrims per year. It is the most popular of the Six Abodes of Murugan.
  • The nearby Tiruchendur temple, also dedicated primarily to Lord Murugan, receives a similar number of pilgrims.
  • Returning to the the Himalayan theme, another of the most popular temples in India is Amarnath Cave Temple in Kashmir, which received as many as 6.3 million pilgrims in its most popular year. It is dedicated to Shiva in His form as Lord Amarnath, a large Shiva Linga made of solid ice. Engulfed in the snow-clad mountains, it is only accessible from June to August, and even then only via a five-day trek with uncertain weather.
  • Meenakshi Temple in Madurai, Tamil Nadu receives as many as six million annual pilgrims by some estimates. This temple is dedicated to the Goddess Meenakshi, and renowned for its wonderful architecture.
  • Attukal Bhagavathy Temple near the heart of the city of Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, dedicated to the Goddess Kannaki Bhadrakali, has a major annual women’s festival, the Attukal Pongal festival. The number of women who attend this festival has reached as high as 4.9 million. The Goddesses Maha Saraswati, Maha Lakshmi, and Maha Kali are all worshipped here.
  • Somnath Temple in Prabhas Kshetra, Saurashtra, Gujarat is another of the most revered twelve Jyotirlinga temples, praised in ancient scriptures like Shiva Mahapurana and Skanda Mahapurana. It receives 4.5 million annual pilgrims. It is said that the Moon God Soma built the original Somnath Temple to thank Lord Shiva for curing him of an ancient curse. It is also near the site where Lord Krishna ended His mortal life in this world.
  • Mahabodhi Mahavira Temple in Bodh Gaya, Bihar receives four million pilgrims per year, mostly Buddhists. It was built by the famous King Ashoka to mark the auspicious site where Siddhartha Gautama attained Enlightenment and became a Buddha. The temple also carefully preserves the direct line of descendants of the original Bodhi Tree, the tree under which Siddhartha Gautama attained Enlightenment.
  • Sabarimala Temple on a hilltop in the Western Ghats in Pathanamthitta District, Kerala receives 3.2 million pilgrims per year. It is dedicated to Lord Ayyappa. It is reached by a long trek on foot, during a rather narrow window of the year, as the temple is closed to visitors at all other times.
  • Kandariya Mahadeva Temple in Khajuraho, Madhya Pradesh receives 2.79 million visitors per year, many of whom also visit some of the 19 other temples in the complex. These temples are famous for their explicit erotic carvings, and host the annual Khajuraho Dance Festival.
  • Kamakhya Temple, nestled in the Blue Hill in Guwahati, Assam, receives 2.5 million pilgrims per year. Dedicated to the Goddess Kamru Kamakhya, this temple is the first and foremost of the fifty-one great Shakti Peethas or primary Shakti temples, and it is said to be the very birthplace of Shakta Tantra. This incredibly sacred temple houses the Yoni of the Goddess Sati. I wrote this answer about it:
Devala Rees
· Jan 17
What’s so special about Maa Kamakhya Teerth? Why is it glorified so profoundly in Devi Maha Bhagavat Puran?
Kamakhya Teertha is one of the most special and sacred sites in all of Shakta Dharma. Of the fifty-one Maha Shakti Peethas across south Asia, Kamakhya Teertha is the most popular and renowned; it is considered the first and foremost of them, and the very birthplace of Shakta Tantra. It receives 2.5 million pilgrims per year. The sacred story of the Shakti Peethas goes that upon the death of the ancient Goddess Sati, Her body was shredded into many pieces (fifty-one main pieces) that were scattered across South Asia. Where each body part fell, a temple was raised to worship Her there. Kamakhya Teertha is the holy site where the Goddess’s Yoni (vagina) fell to Earth. But this was no coincidence, for according to the Kalika Purana, the site that became Kamakhya Teertha, on the beautiful Blue Hill (Nilachala or Nila Parvata) of Assam, was a spot where Sati used to go in secret to satisfy her amour with Shiva, and so her Yoni was drawn back to this site as if by magnetic attraction. The name of the Goddess, Kamru Kamakhya, shows that her Yoni is seen primarily as an organ of Her sexual pleasure, and only secondarily for reproductive purposes. Indeed Kamakhya is considered to be the very embodiment of Kama or pleasure. The Goddess’s intense desire and pleasure is understood in a profound mystical sense by the Tantrik masters, referring to Her overwhelming longing, even lust, to unite in ecstatic union with the pure consciousness or Shiva-Tattwa, including the consciousness of Her devotees who merge into Her through the fulfillment of the path of Maha Tantra and experience the infinite bliss of the Divine Union. Thus Kamakhya Teertha is seen as the place on Earth where the Divine most intently longs to unite with devotees. She is worshipped there in the form of an ancient stone Yoni. To this day, Kamakhya Teertha is one of the most revered centers of Tantrik practices, mysticism, and sorcery. It unites both Dakshinachara (Right-Handed) and Vamachara (Left-Handed) Tantra in its worship customs, and hosts the largest festival assembly of Tantriks in the world, the annual Ambubachi or Ambuvasi Mela. Tantriks from far and wide, and from far disparate schools of Tantra, return here to the birthplace of their traditions once a year to worship Kamru Kamakhya together. She is worshipped both with bloody animal sacrifices and other Vamachara rites, as well as the Sattwik and sanitary rites of the Dakshina path. Specifically this festival celebrates the menstruation of the Goddess as an intensely sacred event, and the whole area is awash with the holy power of Her blood. A wet red cloth, symbolizing the Goddess’s used menstrual pad, is passed around to visitors as sacred Prasad, as well as red-colored water to drink. Kāmākhye Varade Devī Nīla Parvata Vāsinī Twaṁ Devī Jagataṁ Mātā Yonimudre Namostute! (Oh Goddess Kamakhya, boon-giver, dweller on the Blue Hill, Thou, O Goddess, art the Mother of the World. I bow to Thee in the form of the Yoni!)

I could keep on going indefinitely, but those are some of the most popular temples in India.

Vasant Narayan Deshmukh
